title: Triple-Negative Invasive Ductal Carcinoma
setup_script: A 38-year-old woman discovers a 3 cm firm mass in the right upper inner quadrant. Core biopsy reveals grade 3 invasive ductal carcinoma that is triple negative (ER-/PR-/HER2-). Sentinel lymph node biopsy shows 1 of 3 positive nodes.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Review patient history including reproductive factors, genetic risk, and prior breast disease; perform complete exam.
Order staging workup: bilateral mammography, breast MRI, and CT chest/abdomen/pelvis to rule out metastasis.
Discuss aggressive nature of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) and importance of systemic chemotherapy.
Refer to medical oncology; plan neoadjuvant chemotherapy (anthracycline and taxane based) to downstage tumor.
Monitor tumor response clinically and with imaging during treatment.
After completion of chemotherapy, reassess for breast conserving surgery versus mastectomy; consider genetic testing (BRCA1/2).
Plan for lumpectomy with axillary sampling or completion axillary dissection depending on nodal involvement; discuss reconstruction if mastectomy chosen.
Obtain informed consent; explain risk of recurrence and benefit of radiation therapy following breast conserving surgery.
Perform surgery with adequate margins; send sentinel nodes for pathology; proceed to axillary dissection if indicated.
Postoperative care: manage wound, drains, and lymphedema prevention; refer to physical therapy.
Resume systemic therapy if indicated and arrange adjuvant radiation to the breast and regional nodes.
Plan surveillance and discuss lifestyle changes; provide genetic counseling and psychosocial support.

critical_decision_points: Understanding aggressive nature of TNBC and importance of neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
Deciding between lumpectomy and mastectomy after tumor response and genetic considerations.
Appropriate axillary management and reconstruction options.
Postoperative care including lymphedema prevention and radiation therapy.
Provision of genetic counseling and survivorship planning.
